awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 to Support High-Throughput Sequencing Collaborative Research and Integrated Training
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to The University of Tennessee, Knoxville (UTK) to acquire an Illumina NovaSeq sequencer, which will be broadly accessible to on-campus and external researchers through the Genomics Core within the Center for Environmental Biotechnology. The new instrumentation will enable UTK researchers to attain a level of competency more attuned to the breadth of research across the institution’s portfolio of microbial, plant, human, and animal nucleic acid sequencing needs. The expanded Genomics Core will engage a broader cohort of researchers to obtain sequence data, provide faculty new means of illustration of the genes-to-ecosystem concept, and excite more young minds about discovery-driven scientific research and the exploration of the rules of life. A robust network of outreach activities that align with NSF’s STEM educational mission will be strategically integrated into new training and learning opportunities involving the NovaSeq. The newly enabled research will address fundamental research questions that impact the applied sciences and engineering disciplines, and several projects will be of considerable public interest. 

The NovaSeq sequencing instrument bestows the ability to perform demanding nucleic acid sequencing projects allowing researchers to assess the entire genetic makeup of a single organism (e.g., a bacterium, a fungus, or an animal), or an assembly of different microorganisms in a specific habitat (i.e., a microbiome). DNA sequencing will reveal microbial taxonomy and functional potential, and metatranscriptome sequence data will shed light on the actual activities that result in observable characteristics (i.e., organismal phenotypes). Research projects will link microbiome sequence information with processes relevant to environmental, animal, and human health. Sequence-enabled research projects will advance understanding of microbes that detoxify pollutants, control greenhouse gas emission, and promote carbon dioxide sequestration in (agricultural) soils; generate new opportunities for ecologically informed control of biocorrosion and biofouling; allow integrated cross-kingdom analyses to reveal host-microbiome interactions and genetic and epigenetic mechanisms that determine phenotypes; compare lives of contemporary and ancient peoples; explore microbiomes in understudied environments, such as the deep subsurface; and provide new insights into viral ecology and emerging viral diseases (i.e., zoonoses).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Illumina NovaSeq was installed at the University of Tennessee Genomics Core (UTGC) in February 2022. Prior to purchasing the NovaSeq, the UTGC contained an Illumina MiSeq, which could produce up to 25 million clusters/pairs of reads per run. Projects utilizing the MiSeq increased with the arrival of the NovaSeq, requiring the aging MiSeq to be upgraded to an Illumina NextSeq in June 2024. The NextSeq can produce up to 400 million clusters/pairs of reads per run, with smaller flow cell options also available, and quality and cost that is proving superior to the aging MiSeq. We also added a smaller Illumina iSeq, which can produce up to 4 million clusters/pairs of reads per run, for testing runs to improve performance prior to the larger, more expensive NovaSeq runs. The NovaSeq produces up to 10 Billion clusters/pairs of reads per run, with many flow cell and lane sharing options, allowing the UTGC to expand our sequencing offerings to larger genome and RNAseq projects that require greater depth of coverage. The UTGC is now able to cover most sequencing projects for our users, with an improved efficiency, quality, and lower costs.

The UTGC remains located in the Science and Engineering Research Facility. The main lab is approximately 800 ft2 and houses the Illumina sequencing equipment, along with the majority of the library prep equipment such as laminar flow hoods, thermal cyclers, EpMotion 5075 liquid handling robot, and an Agilent Bioanalyzer for DNA visualization and quantification. In April 2024, due to the increasing usage of the UTGC from the NovaSeq sequencing, the UTGC was able to obtain additional lab space in the building, allowing us to expand and offer some additional services. We now have an approximately 260 ft2 new lab space, which houses a dedicated DNA extraction room, as well as some peripheral lab equipment including a Nanodrop8 for DNA quantification and gel electrophoresis equipment. We also have an approximately 225 ft2 laboratory, which is becoming a common use room for users, with equipment that can be accessed as both assisted-use and unassisted-use services, as well as shared use bench space.

Projects began consistently coming into the lab for the NovaSeq in July 2022, and the number of both projects and samples is steadily increasing. Through the completion of the NSF MRI funding period, we have completed 98 projects for 104 unique users, representing 12 departments (4 colleges) within the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, as well as UT Health Science Center (UTHSC) in Memphis, Oak Ridge National Labs (ORNL), and 6 additional external facilities. The projects have spanned a variety of applications, with the majority being RNAseq (totaling 1,820 samples), whole genome or metagenome sequencing (totaling 2,238 samples), and pooled amplicon sequencing (totaling 8,179 samples). Custom library builds have included Hi-C libraries, single cell libraries, TNSeq, Cut & Run, ATAC-Seq, and unique heavily multiplexed amplicons such as small guide RNA fragments. The number of samples for custom libraries is difficult to calculate since they often represent an unknown number of samples to Core staff. From FY23 to FY24, the number of samples processed increased from 2,362 to 9,289 but we ran the instrument fewer times, due to increased pooling capacity and therefore more cost savings to our users.

While the amount of data produced by the NovaSeq generally is outside the scope of quick data analysis needed for classes, Illumina sequencing and data analysis are a part of many classes on the UT campus. The UTGC lab manager teaches a class through the Microbiology department allowing students direct hands-on lab experience of extracting DNA and building a library for sequencing, previously on the Illumina MiSeq and now on the Illumina NextSeq. The class includes a discussion of the various sequencing instruments, how to choose what is right for your project, and a tour of the lab to see the instruments. Lab tours are offered for any class that utilizes sequencing or bioinformatics.

The amount of data produced by the NovaSeq has necessitated some collaborations with other groups on campus. Data is now sent to users through the Office of Innovative Technologies (OIT) High Performance Scientific Computing (HPSC) group, utilizing the university’s cluster network. Data is stored locally and can be analyzed on the ISAAC network or transferred to users’ desktop computers through the Globus data transfer network.

For bioinformatic data analysis support, we developed collaborations with two additional units on campus. The first is Dr. Jon Beever’s group, the UT Institute of Agriculture (UTIA) Genomic Center for the Advancement of Agriculture, who provide project design and bioinformatic support, hiring Dr. Trevor Freeman for this role. We also collaborate with Dr. Meg Staton and Dr. Ryan Kuster with the UTIA Computational Genomics Consulting group for data analysis support for our users.

Modified by: Stephanie N Kivlin
